docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: ACQUITTAL IN DIVORCE CASE A Manhattan lawyer was acquitted yesterday of charges that he bribed a court clerk to alter paperwork relating to a divorce and to speed the case through the judicial system. The lawyer, Dean Emmanuelli, had been indicted on 38 counts of bribery and charged with paying a clerk $40 for each of 37 divorce applications handled last year. Another lawyer accused of offering bribes pleaded guilty last year, as did the supervising clerk for matrimonial cases in Manhattan State Supreme Court who was accused of accepting bribes. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The South African edition of Ebony magazine, introduced nearly five years ago in the afterglow of the country's triumph over apartheid, has shut down after failing to find profits or many readers. On newsstands around the country, a few left-over copies of last month's issue are all that remains of Ebony South Africa.

headline.main: Ebony Ends Publication in South Africa

docs.abstract: Johnson Publishing shuts down South African edition of Ebony magazine, which has failed to find profits or many readers in the nearly five years since it began; prosperity has been slower than expected in reaching the country's black majority, and, as a result, the retail market had little interest in advertising to black consumers, and there was little room for a publication celebrating a level of success that few black people in South Africa can yet conceive, let alone achieve; photo (M)
